comments.author: Lauren
comments.content: "The first rule of potstickers is that you can never make enough potstickers."  Amen to that!

lovely!
As I told you yesterday I tried my gyozas (well, guotie to be honest) with seitan and mushrooms and they were really tasty!
Your recipe is definitely more Jap-style than mine so I'll surely try, thanks! ;)

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: I think your filling sounds good too!

comments.author: Liz
comments.content: Love the idea of tempeh in the filling! I always order gyoza in restaurants but have been fiddling with a meatless version with mixed results - a little too watery, not enough flavor distinction.

comments.content: Just found your blog through foodgawker, and I'm so glad I did.  The recipe looks amazing!  I can't wait to try them!

comments.author: Trudy
comments.content: Yum Yum Yum!! I love vegetarian gyoza... great recipe!!

comments.author: arugulove
comments.content: Looks so good.  I have to confess, the frozen ones at Trader Joe's are a freezer staple of mine, but it's good to know how to make real ones.  I'm sure they are so much better!

comments.author: baobabs
comments.content: looks perfect!!

comments.author: alessandra@clear.net.nz
comments.content: I love Gyoza and it is so difficult to find some good vegetarian ones....actually, quite difficult to find them in Japan! But I didn't know that they were also called potstickers :-)

comments.author: The Wind Attack
comments.content: I love potstickers.  So good.  I fill mine with bok choy, baked tofu and shitake mushrooms... of course along with garlic and ginger.  I actually was planning on making some tonight... before even reading this post.  Been looking forward to them all week.

comments.author: Charlottes Vegetarian Blog
comments.content: You are my new best friend! There is a place in my city that serves these and I was looking for a recipe for them. I've stolen your recipe and using it this weekend :)

comments.author: Ambuja W
comments.content:
"The first rule of potstickers is that you can never make enough potstickers."

I found that out the hard way when i made them for the first time a few weeks ago. Made a mental note to double the recipe next time! Love the idea of tempeh. Will try that next time!

comments.author: Megan
comments.content: I have been looking all over for potsticker recipes-I love that I came across this vegetarian version! I will definitely be trying these out soon-thanks so much for posting :)

comments.author: Fairly-Odd-Tofu-Mom
comments.content: Oh the tempeh is a GREAT idea! I love them with mushrooms, but they have to be well cooked and pulverized somehow so there's no water-y-ness in the dumplings. I'm going to have to try tempeh!

comments.author: kim
comments.content: I crave dumplings at least twice a week and usually end up succumbing to the dumpling place around the corner, but on the off occasion that I make them, I use a filler made of chopped seitan, ginger, and kimchi [so I guess that makes it mandoo and not gyoza, eh?].  I will definitely try your filler though, I bet tempeh lends a great texture!

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Your filling sounds delicious! Are you vegetarian? If so, have you found a veg brand of kimchi that you like? I haven't had much luck. Or do you make your own?

comments.author: kim
comments.content: replied via email [oops?], but the one prepackaged kimchi we found and liked okay had an asian lady on the front

comments.author: joyce
comments.content: i had to join in the praising of this recipe! made them last night and they were gone in a flash! silly me, thought i made too many and would have to freeze them - ha!

comments.author: Kasia
comments.content: Hi, thanks for the good filling ideas :D Your recipes and photos are definitely among the vegetarian high class. But I do have 2 remarks: first of all, Chinese Jiaozi are NOT potstickers, they are always boiled in a big pot like pierogi. I come from Poland so I know my way around with the latter, and I made Jiaozi already together with Chinese friends, so I know that too. Second, which results from the first, I know how to make those "wrappers" and all you need is (preferably high protein) flour, water and lots of kneading and rolling out :) Some gyoza skins may contain eggs, but this is not generally common, the trick is the high protein flour, the eggs are sometimes used if the flour does not have high quality. The "wrappers" are only sold as a time saving short cut, it may be even healthier to prepare them at home, since some Asian convenience products tend to contain not so healthy additives, which are not always listed :/ It is not difficult to prepare those wrappers, if you ever made Polish pierogi (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pierogi), you can make homemade Jiaozi wrappers too, those are just thinner and more springy (the high protein trick). I admit I use the Jiaozi dough method at home when I make pierogi since I saw the great results, and it is also good when eggs are a problem for health reasons or for vegans.

comments.author: Kasia
comments.content: It seems the Wikipedia link does not work for some strange reason, so here :): http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pierogi

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Thanks for the encouragement to make our own wrappers, it sounds fun. I've never made pierogi, but it doesn't sound intimidating. Re the name, see the wikipedia page for Jiaozi under the Chinese section - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gyoza - jiaozi is generic for dumpling, there are subvariants for steamed (shuijiao), pan fried (guotie), and boiled (zhengjiao).

comments.author: Lian
comments.content:
Good Recipe,
But there is definitely an american perspective here, also if you really believe that this traditional Chinese dish is based on a "umami" mass, i really don't know what to say.

Potstickers are traditionally made after dumplings are boiled first, like leftovers. Also, you should be looking for a even taste with the filling, not chunks of ingredients, so a food processor is more fitting here for the cabbage and scallions.

Methodology for the actual cooking is very spot on.

comments.author: Xiaolu @ 6 Bittersweets
comments.content: I love love dumplings of all sorts. Never tried potstickers with tempeh, but I can imagine it adds some nice heft to the filling.

comments.author: Kate
comments.content: I've been a quiet reader of your wonderful blog for a while... you are always so inspiring for my veggie needs.  I usually rely on TJ's frozen gyozas, yet I made these tonight and as always your professional tips helped a lot -- thanks Michael!

comments.author: Nicole
comments.content:
There definitely can never be enough gyoza! In China I ordered them by weight and made many a meal out of them.

When my husband & I make gyoza, we make about 100.  No joke.  It's a Sunday afternoon with a movie affair to roll them all up. I've been using marinated and crumbled extra-firm tofu, but I'm intrigued by using Tempeh.  I think it's it would be perfect in Gyoza.  I usually stick finely minced carrots in mine as well.

comments.author: julie chang
comments.content: I substituted homemade kimchee for the cabbage, chopped and well-squeezed to remove moisture. Instead of crumbling the tempeh, next time I will try processing about half to give it a better texture, not so crumbly. Also, a tablespoon of corn or potato starch in the water for steaming will add extra crispyness to the bottoms of the potstickers.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: @julie - Thanks for the interesting tip about adding the starch, I could see how that would work.

comments.author: axel g
comments.content:
That's a beautiful recipe!

I took a liking to this kind of food while living in Japan.

Tempura is another favorite of mine.

Nicely presented post +_+

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Thanks, Axel! I've got another kind of potsticker coming up soon, Korean style.

comments.author: Tina Lee
comments.content: I make this gyoza few days ago. It tasted delicious. I couldn’t find ready made gyoza skin locally, hence I prepared it from scratch. The skin turns out fine and not too doughy. The trick of getting paper thin skin is using the dimsum ">http://www.bakingfrenzy.com/bamboo-rolling-pin-p-340.html"> wooden rolling pin which allows me to apply equal pressure on the dough to get the paper thin edge. This gyoza go well with Japanese Gyoza dipping sauce.

comments.author: Stephanie
comments.content: We made these for Super Bowl today, they were great, the second package of tempeh I bought looked like it had gone off, so I substituted an equal amount of extra firm tofu also fried up in advance of incorporating it.  I cooked the first dozen the way you instructed, and they were great, but stuck pretty badly and therefore several of them broke apart, so I just copped out and steamed the rest of them, but they were all delicious and a fun party food :)  Thanks!

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content:
I'm glad you liked them! And I'm wondering why you had sticking issues. Were you careful to cook until the water was completely gone at step 5? That tends to be key.


Thanks,
Michael

comments.author: lily
comments.content: yea those trader joe's freezer gyoza have gotten me in a lot of trouble

comments.author: Sabrina
comments.content: Hi Michael, quick question... What does tempeh taste like? Is it similar to tofu? And what brand do you recommend?

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Hey Brina - tempeh is quite a bit different from tofu. It is more dense and has a pronounced flavor. I like it best when it is well browned in a hot pan with plenty of oil. No specific brand recommendations. Usually Whole Foods or similar stores will have one or two choices.

comments.author: Kristy Schmidt
comments.content: I love love dumplings! Never tried potstickers with tempeh, but am sure it is in the works here shortly.  Thanks for sharing this on http://grubodex.com!

comments.author: Kristy Schmidt
comments.content:
Oh lord, vegetarian potstickers, yumm!! 
http://grubodex.com/index.php/component/socialpinboard/pin?pinid=371

comments.author: Michelle
comments.content:
These potstickers are excellent! 
I decided to freeze some, just to keep myself from eating them all in one sitting. They freeze very well, and cook up just as tasty from frozen. 

Thanks Julie, I look forward to trying kimchee in my next batch.

comments.author: Penny F.
comments.content:
Michelle I was wondering about freezing these...did you cook them up first then freeze or freeze
before frying?

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: You should freeze them raw, in a single layer not touching each other on a baking sheet, then when they are frozen you can put them in a bag. Fry them up just before serving - the instructions in the recipe will work just fine, it will just take slightly longer.

comments.author: Penny F.
comments.content: Thanks, that was what I had hoped to do.  I'm looking forward to trying these!

comments.author: Michelle
comments.content: Yes I did what Michael said, & having them in your freezer is a gift that keeps on giving. Great for a spontaneous meal that will impress!

comments.author: smt
comments.content: How thin do you slice the tempeh before frying it?

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Around 1/3" will work well.

comments.author: vanessa
comments.content: made these tonight, good stuff!  added a little fresh ginger.  thanks for the recipe.

comments.author: Jamie
comments.content: I bet seitan could be a good substitute for tempeh.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Yep, it would be a bit different texture, more chewy, but I agree it could be very good.
